Item:  6.02
	 
	 
Recognition presented to Iliana Esperanza Ozuna.  Iliana dedicated her 13th birthday to assist our McKinney-Vento students and their families.  She completed a half marathon of 13.1 miles, appropriately named "Esperanza (hope) Running" and raised over $3,500!  Iliana was able to provide thermals for males, fleece leggings for females, and a scarf, gloves and socks for each student and their siblings.  She also provided Christmas stockings of pencils, toys and candy for the younger children.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.04
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Curtis Matthews, from Moss Adams, LLP
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action Regarding Measure E, G and I Bond Fund Performance Audit Report for the Fiscal Years Ended June 30, 2014, and June 30, 2015
	 
This presentation covers the results of our performance audit of the East Side Union High School District’s (ESUHSD or the District) 2015 Measure E, G and I Construction Bond (Bond Program) as required by California Proposition 39. 
California State (State) requirements specify that the proceeds from the sale of school facilities bonds are expended only on the specific projects listed in the proposition authorizing the sale of bonds. 
Both the State Constitution and the Education Code require an annual independent performance audit to verify Bond proceeds are used on Listed Projects. An annual financial audit is also required by these rules. 
Generally Accepted Government Auditing Standards (GAGAS) are required and define the term performance audit and related professional standards.
This presentation also covers and review of the District Construction, Maintenance and Facilities Department's (Facilities) performance and controls surrounding the Bond Program for the Fiscal Year ended June 30, 2014, and the Fiscal Year ended June 30, 2015
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Measure E, G and I Bond Fund Performance Audit Report for the Fiscal Years Ended June 30, 2014, and June 30, 2015, as presented.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Associate Superintendent of Human Resources
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m. Regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: from East Side Union High School District to California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187, for the 2016-2017 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547, the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its classified employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  
Accordingly, the District proposes the following areas for contract negotiations: total compensation, which includes salary and benefits (Articles 15 and 16); contract language amendments to Article 8: Reclassification; Article 17: Vacation; Article 19: Holidays; Article 20.7: Overtime; and Article 26: Term.  The District also has an interest in ensuring that contract language  is consistent with current funding formulas; eliminating references to COLA.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board sunshine and accept any public comment on the District’s initial proposal to the California Employees Association, Chapter 187.

FROM:

Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services, and Teresa Marquez, Director of Professional Development and Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Proposal for Use of the Educator Effectiveness Grant Funds Allocated by the California Department of Education
	 
The Educator Effectiveness Grant (EEG) has been allocated to LEAs to provide beginning teacher and administrator support and mentoring, professional development, coaching and support services for teachers identified as needing improvement or additional support, professional development for teachers and administrators aligned to the state standards, and to promote educator quality and effectiveness.  The proposed plan will outline and detail how the funds will be utilized.

Tier I and Tier II clearing of credential program for administrators with a preliminary credential.  Coaching support for administrators to further build their leadership skills.

Professional development concentrated on:
					•   Student Production at or above Depth of Knowledge level 3 (DOK 3)
					•   Lesson/Task design
					•   Content Specific Curriculum and Instruction Development,  i.e.
					•   Next Generation Science Standards  (NGSS)
					•   Mathematics Teacher Driven Collaboration
					•   Social Studies Primary Source Modules
					•   Literacy and accommodation strategies.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
The District will receive $1466 per FTE to be used over the course of 3 years.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
California Department of Education
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed plan for the use of the Educator Effectiveness Grant funds.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Administrative Job Description and Salary Range for Multi-Tiered Systems of Support (MTSS) Coordinator
	 
	 
The lack of availability of processes and procedures for systematic interventions to prevent inappropriate referrals and identification for special education has been identified as a systemic issue in a study of the district by WestEd in 2013 and again most recently in the 2015 Audit by the California Department of Education, as well as anecdotally by East Side principals, psychologists and Instructional Division staff.   Over 300 requests for assessment were processed during the 2014-2015 school year. 
	In order to address this system deficit and provide a method and model of interventions to support students, a model of Multi-Tiered Systems of Support (MTSS) is recommended. Funded through the Coordinated Early Intervening Services (CEIS) fund, the position of MTSS Coordinator will work with sites to develop the model which will begin to address the systemic issues of over-referral and over-identification, as required through the CEIS program.
The District is requesting the approval of the administrative job description and salary range for Multi-Tiered Systems of Support (MTSS) with an annual salary of $81,028 - $117,305.  This is a 12 month Administrative position.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$81,028 – $117,305 per year
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
CEIS funding
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
	It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Administrative job description and salary range for Multi-Tiered Systems of Support (MTSS) Coordinator.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Board Policy 4262 (New) Substitute Differential Pay for Classified Service Employees on Maternity or Paternity Leave (effective February 1, 2016), and to Waive Board Bylaw 9310 Requiring Second Reading of Proposed New or Amended Board Policy
	 
At the December 10, 2015, Regular Board Meeting, the Board took action to adopt Board Policy 4162 (New) and Amended Board Policy 4361 to implement effective January 1, 2016, the differential pay requirements under AB 375 for persons employed in a position requiring certification qualifications who have exhausted all available sick leave, including all accumulated sick leave, and continues to be absent from his or her duties on account of maternity or paternity leave as specified in the law.
Attached for Board consideration is Board Policy 4262 (New) for the application and implementation of similar benefits to District employees who are members of the classified service (not including substitute and short-term classified employees).  If approved by the Board as presented, new Board Policy 4262 would be effective February 1, 2016.
	 
Board Bylaw 9310 provides that the Superintendent or designee shall develop and present a draft policy for a first reading at a public Board meeting, and that the Board may take action on a proposed policy only after a second reading.  Bylaw 9310 further provides that the Board may waive the second reading.  Implementation of new Board Policy 4262 to be effective February 1, 2016, would require the Board to waive the second reading requirement for these policies under Bylaw 9310.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:
Waive the second reading requirement for Board policies under Bylaw 9310 as to draft proposed new Board Policy 4262; and
Consider and approve new Board Policy 4262 as presented, to be effective February 1, 2016.

Item:  15.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve to Update the Facilities Master Plan
	 
Board Policy 7110 Facilities Master Plan states that the Governing Board recognizes the importance of long-range planning for school facilities in order to help meet the changing needs of district students and to help ensure that resources are allocated in an efficient and effective manner.  This calls for development and maintenance of a master plan for district facilities.
	 
A Facilities Master Plan (FMP) was last formally updated in March 2004. The FMP was used to inform the capital construction projects executed using Measure G general obligation bond funds.  Although the FMP has not been updated, it has been used – along with the project lists generated by School Site Councils out of the FMP – to inform the planning and project selection processes associated with Measures E and I.
	 
Proposition 39 type bonded indebtedness incurred by a school district for the construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation, or replacement of school facilities must include accountability measures, including a list of the specific school facilities projects to be funded certification that the school district board has evaluated safety, class size reduction, and information technology needs in developing that list.
	 
District staff recommends engaging a firm to update the 2004 Facilities Master Plan.  An updated plan will provide an appropriate framework for pursuit of additional funds to continue the school facilities modernization program, and to execute that program efficiently, effectively and in compliance with Proposition 39 general obligation bond accountability measures.  The planning process will include engagement and collaboration with constituent groups as called for in Board Policy 7110 Facilities Master Plan.
	 
The proposed preliminary timeline for an updated facilities master plan is as follows:
Master plan RFQ/P:  January 2016
Contract award:  March 2016
Master planning:  March – June 2016
Board approval:  August 2016
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable                                                    
                                                                                               
FUNDING SOURCE:
Fund 35 School Facilities Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize administration to solicit proposals for an updated facilities master plan, bring forth a recommendation for a facilities master planning contract award at the March Board meeting, and proceed with the updated facilities master planning initiative per the delineated timeline.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, Traci Williams, Piedmont Hills High School Principal, and Farshid Samsami, Bond Program Manager, SGI
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Revision to the Capital Construction Project List for Piedmont Hills High School
	 
On February 13, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved the 2013 Capital Construction Project Lists for Piedmont Hills High School (Item 15.03).  The Project List included three funded projects:  a new classroom building east of Building L, modernization of Building G, and modernization of Building K into science classrooms.  
	 
Since that time, prior approved projects have been completed and closed out, and projects on the 2013 Project Lists were initiated, including award of contracts for construction management and design services.  Design for these three projects has advanced to the 75% schematic design milestone.  In addition to review of as-built record documents for existing structures and numerous site visits, the design and construction management teams have met with school representatives on eight occasions to validate program requirements, receive feedback on classroom layout options, and verify that the projects are within the established budgets.  The resulting schematic designs for the new building and for modernized Building G are satisfactory.  However, due to existing structural shear walls in Building K, the modernization of that building into science classrooms would result in undersized labs whose configurations would not satisfy program requirements.  
	 
The design and construction management teams explored various options that would improve the outcome for the science program.  A new building south of Building D, to include four science classrooms, four general education classrooms, one special education classroom plus support facilities was identified as the most viable option to satisfy science program needs, as well as provide some of the general and special education space that would have been part of the new building east of Building L.  The required funding for this option would necessitate deferment of the Buildings G and K modernizations, as well as the new classroom building east of Building L.
	 
School Site Council recommends development of the new building south of Building D in lieu of modernizing Building K to house science classrooms.  School Site Council further recommends deferring the modernization of Building G and construction of a new building east of Building L, and redirecting that associated funding to the new building south of Building D.  
	 
Superintendent’s Council has reviewed this recommendation, and is in support of the project list revision.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities,  Greg Louie, Santa Teresa High School Principal, and Farshid Samsami, Bond Program Manager, SGI
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Revision to the Capital Construction List for Santa Teresa High School
	 
On February 13, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved the 2013 Capital Construction Project Lists for Santa Teresa High School (Item 15.03).  The Project List included nine funded projects.  On May 14, 2015, the Board approved de-funding of the Gymnasium Building 700 Foyer Modernization and Tennis Courts Expansion projects so that Santa Teresa could redirect funding to a larger swimming pool (Item 15.01).
	 
Since that time, prior approved projects have been completed and closed out, and projects on the 2013 Project Lists were initiated, including award of contracts for construction management, design services and a pre-engineered science classroom/restroom building for Phoenix High School.  While design work on most of these projects is well underway, the Upgrade Building 100, Room 101 Life Skills Studio project is no longer a project that Santa Teresa High School is interested in pursuing.  In the time that the project list was developed by site constituents and administration, and reviewed by District administration, Calero High School was just opening.  Calero has become a successful post senior program space, and is a local resource to Santa Teresa’s community.  Calero’s geographical adjacency allows Santa Teresa to focus its resources on standard academic curriculum, and for Calero to offer life skills curriculum in a post senior environment.
	 
At the same time, Santa Teresa is realizing an increased demand for science classroom facilities.  The current science department collaboration space is in Building 400, Room 410 – a location with existing utilities and adjacency to science prep rooms – making it ideal for conversion to an additional science classroom.  The department collaboration space can be relocated to Building P1.
	 
Concurrently, design work is advancing for the new Science Classroom and Restrooms for Phoenix High School, along with development of a new Student Courtyard to provide an appropriate outdoor environment.  The new building and courtyard will result in the loss of approximately three dozen parking spaces in that area of the campus.  The adjacent underutilized basketball courts can be repurposed to replace the lost parking.
	 
School Site Council recommends revising the Life Skills Studio project budget to cover the very small amount of expenditures that have been realized to date, and cancelling the project.  School Site Council further recommends converting Room 410 into an additional science classroom, and converting the basketball courts on the south side of campus to mitigate parking loss due to the Phoenix mini-campus development.
	 
Superintendent’s Council has reviewed this recommendation, and is in support of the project list revision.

RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:
Approve Santa Teresa High School Site Council’s recommendation and Superintendent’s Council’s concurrence to cancel the Life Skills Studio project, and revise the project budget to $15,000 to cover expenditures.
Approve Santa Teresa High School Site Council’s recommendation and Superintendent’s Council’s concurrence to initiate a New Science classroom in Room 410, Relocation of Science Collaboration Office to Building P1 project, with an associated project budget of $550,000.
Approve Santa Teresa High School Site Council’s recommendation and Superintendent’s Council’s concurrence to initiate the Conversion of South Basketball Courts to Parking project, with an associated budget of $50,000.

SUBJECT:
Receive the Fourth Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period covering October 1, 2015, through December 31, 2015, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
BACKGROUND
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints, if any, filed from October 1, 2015, through December 31, 2015. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the Fourth Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Report for the period covering October 1, 2015, through December 31, 2015, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

SUBJECT:
Ratification of Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services At or Below $50,000  
					 
					 
The attached lists the Bond/Capital Projects Contracts for Professional Services at or below $50,000 being recommended for Board ratification. 
					 
Fiscal Impact:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Funding Source:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services at or below $50,000 as recommended in the attachment and authorization is being requested for the Superintendent and/or designee to execute amendments to the Agreement that may be needed during the term, provided such amendments do not: (i) extend the term of the contract; (ii) increase the price of goods or services provided under the contract by the greater of ten percent (10%) of the contract amount (based on the original contract amount exclusive of any approved amendments in the aggregate); or (iii) alter the quality or quantity of services or goods provided under the Board-approved contract per Board Policy 3312.1.
